reviewText:
Early Access Review

At its current stage in devlopment, Parkitect is a very promising theme park game.

It is very similar to the Rollercoaster Tycoon(RCT) series of games, it feels like a hybrid between RCT2 and RCT3, taking the best bits from both.

The rollercoaster editor/creator in this game is brilliant, it works like the one in the RCT games but has additional features such as the ability to change the size of a track piece.
Because the coaster editor is similar to RCT it means you can't make exact replicas of real coasters but you can get really close with the help of the new additions.

The scenery/decoration editor is solid and very easy to use, just like in RCT2.

The animations on flat rides are absolutely gorgeous, they are realistic and so smooth.
The graphics are what you expect for this sort of game, they are vibrant and simple.

The interface to this game is very simple and looks nice and sleek.

The current selection of available attractions is small but the attractions that are available are fantastically made and look as good as they can.

Now on to the less than great things (All of which will most likely go away as the game is developed):
Not enough attractions, there needs to be more content to make a full sized park.
Not enough coaster types, again there needs to be more coasters.
No career/scenarios, currently there is only sandbox.
(really nitpicky) Not stable, obviously with the game being in alpha the game isn't that stable, if your park becomes large and popular, there will be lag.


So all in all this game is currently pretty good and so long as the devs don't do what most Early Access devs do it'll turn in to a legendary game.

Now stop faffing around reading reviews and go buy it.

Let me begin with, I was one of the individuals who contributed to the Kickstarter to help this game become a reality. Heck, I remember when Sebastian was showing off his concept work using programmer art to demonstrate the systems he was working on. Then Garret hopped on the train and the game REALLY took off. I would liken this game to a beautiful fusion of the original Theme Park by Bullfrog and RollerCoaster Tycoon 2. I will explain the how and why later on in my review. This game as a whole is a massive labor of love by everyone involved and it truly shines because of this.

Gameplay:
The game plays exactly how you would expect a Theme Park simulator to play. You paint paths, place rides and shops, build coasters of doom- I uh mean Thrilling Coasters!1!!1, and hire staff for your park. On top of that you also are in charge of planting scenery, constructing buildings, terra-forming, adding water to your park, and so much more! If you have played RollerCoaster Tycoon then a lot of this will feel very similar and you can easily dive in with a few quirks. A feature in Parkitect that the RollerCoaster Tycoon games lack is a shopkeeper and stock system. This was present in Bullfrogs Theme Park in the form of a graph like GUI where you order stock for your burger shop or drink stall through delivery trucks. In Parkitect you hire Haulers" who are staff members that will exit the park to pickup crates and deliver them to their respective stalls. This adds an additional layer of strategy on the game because you can either have your Haulers carry boxes through your park in plain sight or you have the option of constructing employee only paths that can hide behind the scenes or travel underground! To top this off the Staff Paths can also lead to a building I wish we had in the RollerCoaster Tycoon series

For being in Early Access, Parkitect has a great start to becoming a fairly limit-less and really fun amusement park management sim. The game has a lot of content right now - although it is just a sandbox, at this point. There is a lot to build and manage. From custom rollercoasters and buildings to Steam Workshop support, you will definately have plenty to entertain yourself if you have the imagination.

While I was not as 'blown away' with this as a majority of the reviews, I think it comes down to getting out what you put in. Like a box of Legos, you have to entertain yourself. There is no tutorial here, or end goal. It is really not that hard to keep your budget in the black, either.

Pros:
+Graphics and art style really work well here.
+Controls are intuitive and work really well.
+It is a modernization of Roller Coaster Tycoon, with all the goodness of that series and some added in things that are a breath of fresh air.

Cons:
-It could benefit from a fairly in-depth tutorial (which I assume is likely to be added), so no biggie.
-It needs music! Currently there is only one track for all the rides (the same track), and its hella annoying (classic carnie music).
-Keep the content coming!
-Other small things that you would expect from an alpha Early Access game.

Yeah, if you like amusement park tycoon games, this is a no-brainer.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First of all: Don't buy this game yet if you expect a finished or bug-free product. It's in Alpha state so it's neither feature complete nor bug-free.

This said, the game is well playable for a couple of hours or even a lot more, depending on what parts of the gameplay you emphasize. There's no game-breaking bugs I've encountered or any crashes I've had, just minor stuff like visitors walking through objects or walls or a mechanic stuck in a door.

(I strongly recommend to get the free cam mod from parkitectnexus to replace the isometric perspective with a free-floating camera. This helps immensely when building objects and is overall more fun and looks better.)

You can already:

- build giant rollercoasters of all kinds

- ride those rollercoasters, thanks to a mod

- custom build houses, which your visitors can enter and you can place attractions, food stands or whatever you want in. Base game does not offer the variety of Planet Coaster yet though.

- build a nice variety of attractions, however they're somewhat limited and a park the size of the quarter of the map will likely contain all of them.

- terraform the map to your liking

- download countless mods, custom buildings, new themes, maps via parkitectnexus.com and Steam Workshop

- report bugs you find on the forums

what you can't:

-get your hand held: there's no tutorial, no tooltips. However everything is pretty selfexplanatory imo, all information is visualized somehow. You need spacebar to turn objects and controls for the camera, for everything else there's a button in the UI

- build large parks as the engine isn't optimised and will run into performance issues when zooming out with parks bigger than a quarter of the current map size (means around 700-800 visitors at once, I guess this takes 3-5 hours to achieve)
technically you can build bigger parks of course but to run smoothly you can't zoom the camera out too much.

- manage your park: you can hire personel but that's about it, I think you don't have to pay them yet and can't create zones to assign them to yet (correct me if I'm wrong though, there's a button to assign them to zones, but I can't figure out how to create them)
there's no financial challenge, the park will make plus no matter what. If you lack money, just speed up the game and wait

So, the conclusion: If you're the creative type and just want a sandbox to build the rollercoasters and amusement parks of your dreams I figure there's already dozens of hours of fun in this. If you expect a lot to manage, any scenarios to accomplish or great challenges then you might wanna pass out on this for the time being (but keep an eye on it!)

To break this down, here are the con's and pro's of Parkitect.

Pro's:

- different but realistic features such as shop stocking

o The Haunted House(general ride) and the Suspended Monorail (transport ride)

TL;DRThis game basically is a modern, more flexible version of RCT2. If you've liked designing and building nice sandbox parks for hours and your PC cannot handle more demanding 3D-games, this definitely is for you! A game for designers, architects, coaster-enthusiasts and - hopefully soon - tycoons!

I played RCT1&2 since 2002 and used it mostly as a creative tool for building nice theme parks, so I very early found out about this game as it is very close to the first two installments of the series and thus bought the pre-alpha.

Graphics:First I didn't like the graphics and the perspective of the game, but I grew fond of them because they optimized them and added color filters to tone down the bright hues. And the view is more optimized and mods even add first person functions as well (always wanted to walk around parks in RCT2). There are still some graphic glitches (also due to being able to build so freely) but I'm sure they will be resolved.

Gameplay/building:The grid-based building process is very similar to RCT, but has a lot more freedom because you can overlay multiple objects/walls and place objects like trees, rocks and decorations outside the grid as well.
Coaster building is an extended version of the original RCT coaster builder and allows much smoother transitions and banking of the tracks.
The vanilla rides and objects are sufficient to build nice parks. There are no official coaster or ride brands in the game, but you can easily get the inspirations.

Simulation:The simulation so far works quite well, I had no trouble with the guests or staff so far. I really like the feature of the delivery and the added staff-only paths and staff rooms - something that was missing from RCT. The coasters and rides run smoothly and I love how the graphs for ride intensity/speed or the guests are presented.

UI/Sound:The menus are sometimes a bit confusing, as I found out about features only by asking about them on Reddit, so there's a bit work left to do there. But navigating in them is easy and the search object function is a plus. Cannot say much about the sound, as I'm mostly playing on mute anyways.

Additional:The workshop feature and Parkitect Nexus now are somehow split, so I hope this will get resolved somehow as there are some great custom objects, parks and mods like onride or first person camera available over there already.
For me sometimes there is not enough costumization, which I hope will be added later, especially on the outskirts of parks (parking lots, roads, hotels and a customizable entrance building).
I liked giving feedback to this project, as I have the feeling the creators (who might be overwhelmed due to the Steam release now) listen and improve the game continuously.

Before buying keep in mind:This game is in Early Access = not finished and depending on feedback
The economic features of this game are still in development
There is no tutorial of how to play it, but if you've played RCT1&2 you will find your ways pretty fast
This game has no scenario feature yet
There are bugs in this game, that's why it's in Early Access!

I have been following Parkitect for some time now and was eagerly awaiting the business simulation games release on Steam before I purchased it.

Parkitect is reminiscent of the classic Rollercoaster Tycoon titles, right down to the isometric view and world charm.  In Parkitect, you must build a theme park from the ground up while managing finances, stock and staff.  Personally, this has been one of the most engrossing parts of the gamel; finding new ways to manage and balance finances.  For example, will guests come to your park if you charge a $30 entry fee with all rides at $0.30?  Damn right they will!

The main focus, however is on designing and creating a theme park from scratch.  You will be given a very substantial plot of land and a large amount of cash to get your park off the ground.  From here, you must entice guests to come to Mr. Fun's Funpark of Fun and spend all of their hard earned cash by pulling it from their cold dead hands in any way possible.  People need to pee, right?  Charge for toilet usage!

This game also gives you the ability to build rollercoasters' piece by piece that gives you the power to create the rollercoaster of your dreams, before charging out the ♥♥♥ for it.

The overall look, feel and charm of Parkitect is much like that of RollerCoaster Tycoon. Guests feel like they are experiencing your creations first hand. The ride music and ambience of chattering guests and rattling coasters make sure that your theme park comes to life.

Parkitect seemingly has modding built in it from the ground up, with the game featuring a modding menu and steam workshop integration that is akin to that of Cities: Skylines where players have the ability to create and upload their creations to the Steam Workshop for other business-savy players to make use of.  For example, I was in-game and placed a small eco park right in to the centre of my buzzing theme park.  Simple as that.  I believe that the type of modding integration available in Parkitect will vastly increase the games' longevity.

Right now the only game mode is a sandbox mode where all rides, shops, utilities, paths, etc are unlocked from the get go.  Hopefully in the future, we may see challenge modes or game modes where everything is not unlocked from the beginning.

Hopefully as the games development trundles on we will see the admission of new rides, shops, utilities and decorations. As well as new ways to pressure guests in to funnelling all of their cash in to your dirty corporate pockets.

Parkitect is a title that you should be paying attention to if you have any passing interest in simulation, strategy or management games or have played other titles like Rollercoaster Tycoon, Theme Park World or Theme Hospital.

However, this game is still in Alpha and is constantly being improved upon.  You can keep up-to-date through the developers website or the Steam forums where patch information is posted.

In a time where RollerCoaster Tycoon World exists, you should be buying, or at the very least, keeping an eye on Parkitect.

Developers are definitely dedicated to what they're doing with the game, and update the game regularly at the end of each month, with a bit of information on their progress every weekend.

Now, hear me out. The game is great. It's really nice, but before purchasing - and I'm not being negative here - consider that for now it's a bit lacking in terms of content. The graphics are just right for this type of game, gameplay is satisfying when you watch your park prosper, the UI is very clear and not intrusive, terraforming is damn great, and so on.

The few gripes I have with this game are there only because of it still being in early development. I adore it, and trust me - I don't say that about many Early Access games.

1. The game's performance could be better as it likes to stutter sometimes. It particularly shows when you zoom out.
2. Crowd sounds. Your guests make different sounds, from little songs to laughing and shouting in excitement. And it's fine, it sounds natural... until your park grows to a certain number of guests.

IT IS INFURIATING. By the time you have about 200-300 guests it's hardly bearable. The problem here is that your guests make their sounds over each other. Crowd sounds in RCT were perfect. TL;DR As of 5/5/16, Parkitect has created the old spark that I had as a kid playing the old Roller Coaster Tycoon games (not #3). The game has kept that old-timey feel of locked rotation as well as giving the player the option to rotate the camera freely (to a point). I would recommend it in it's current state 100%. It's pretty decently polished, has the gameplay, and introduces community mods and blueprints to the steam workshop as well as ParkitectNexus.

The Graphics
The graphics in the game are very polished. While it has some glitches here and there, it is an alpha and I look passed that. Parkitect is very aesthetically pleasing in the way of color and presentation. Every time I go in to the game I enjoy looking at it becasue it's not too bright or boring (However, you do get the options to make it boring or very colorful).

8/10

The Gameplay Parkitect offers a lot in terms of gameplay. Right now there is no story mode or campaign. However, there is a Sandbox mode that lets the player pretty much do anything they would like. The game runs pretty smoothly, however in terms of performance, even on my R9 290x it bogs down in some of the bigger maps when zoomed out.

The game gives the player many options for customizations on things such as buildings, landscapes, people, etc. I love that the game gives players the option to follow around certain people and see what they're doing in your park. It helps quite a bit to see how to optimize your park, and where to do so.


*More to come as I get more in depth with the game. Limited time writing and such.

Early Access Review

So far this is basically a clone of Rollercoaster Tycoon, with 3d graphics and less content (sandbox only so far). The graphics are pretty nice but there are some gameplay features that are missing from RCT (there's no research or park scenarios, for example), and not a lot in the way of innovation, though there is stock / inventory system for your shops and kiosks which is new. However, everything that is implemented is super polished and feels like a finished game in terms of quality (just not enough content yet, imo).

Compared to RCT there are some overall improvvements in the interface and details. Placing paths is much easier and you have a lot more control over coaster construction (including being able to customize the bank on curves) though there are some quirks. For example, even though the graphics are 3d the game is still pinned to a x/y grid and some track segments can't be used at 45 degrees. I guess simplifies the engine a bit.

And finally, the big thing missing compared to RCT is the variety. Obviously this game is early in the development stage but I think it will really be more fun later when there is more variety in attractions, coasters, styles, and most importantly, scenarios (and possibly some other kind of content gating). Right now it's a sandbox and although the core mechanics are well executed it's not super compelling in terms of gameplay loop and rewards.

I spent hundreds of hours playing RCT back in the day and this game is so far a dutiful homage to the classic. I'm sure over time as more content is added it will be even more fun, but I'd love to see some innovation in the gameplay or game systems department. If your primary fun factor in RCT was just designing the coasters, you will enjoy what's here so far. But if you got more enjoyment out of the business / sim / scenario side of things that part is not really there yet. Overall I would recommend buying this now if you want to show your support, but wait if you want more content to explore.

Well, the game does speak for itself, mostly.

I like the fact it's an upgraded version of the old Rollercoaster Tycoons. Graphically it looks a lot better.
Also, there's modding; there are camera mods that let you ride your rides, or walk amongst your visitors.
There's a ton of scenery and it's really easy to lose track of time when building your own park.

This is THE sandbox mode we've always wanted in the old Rollercoaster Tycoons.

So, is it all good? No, not really... However, the not-so-great things are all down to this game still being in alpha.
My experience is completely based on the Alpha 9a, which was the version before the Steam EA version.
The game is rather demanding; I've installed the 9a version on my old PC (DualCore 2.6GHz, Radeon HD 7870, 4GB DDR3) for my girlfriend to play with. The game has to be put on lowest settings and still stutters when it's raining and she has more than 100 guests in her park. She doesn't mind, since she isn't a gamer and she's mostly looking at the pretty flowers ;) But it does show a lot of room for optimization - the patch notes did mention a lot of performance improvement in the latest patch, but I have no experience with that patch yet.

The game runs well on my own PC (FX-8150 (OC'd to 4GHz), R9 290 (Asus OC edition) and 8GB DDR3) at stable 60 FPS.

I still do recommend this game for the following reasons:
- if you liked the old RCTs, you'll definitely enjoy this as well.
- it's not expensive at 15 euro
- it's early access, so there's promise for a WHOLE lot more to come
- there's a rather active modding community

Early Access Review

Disclaimer: At the time of writing this review, I have been playing a pre-alpha release for ~40h.

This game is a perfect modernisation of RollerCoasterTycoon2. If you don't care about realistic 3D graphics and riding your coasters, I guarantee you'll have more fun playing Parkitect, than RCTWorld or PlanetCoaster.

It really is a faithful succesor to RCT2. Most acpects of the game are designed to resemble the feel of classic RollerCoasterTycoon, but removing the limits and expanding on available options. The park building mechanisms are similar - yet more powerful and finer-grained. For example, you can divide the grid by 4 for finer precision when placing trees. Track slopes may have as much as 6 tilt levels in both directions. Ride entrances may be turned 90 degrees. The developers clearly are veterans of the classic game, and know very well what made the original so good, and what should be improved.

The modernized graphics style is unique - cartoon asthetics fit the theme perfectly. The game has a very HD feel to it, as the cartoonish style is minimalistic yet plesantly detailed.

There is a wire variety of attractions to build already in the game, but if that's not enough, the mod support is very solid.

And finally, the dev team keeps good contact with the community. There are very frequent updates and the progress done is amazing, they are also open to feedback and ideas.

Strongly recommended for all RCT veterans. For everyone else, you may want to wait a little more - the campaign mode and in-game economy are not yet implemented, and the bare sandbox mode may make the game confusing for newcommers.

As someone who has put thousand of hours into rct 1 & 2 over the years, this game has managed to reignite that lost addiction which is nice.

While ride and scenary options are limited, even with a limited selection there is a ton you can do. Scenary has no space restrictions so you can just overlap and create anything you mind can imagine. Even a coaster that just strolls through a couple boulders for the fun of it. Its very refreshing to see there be no limits on place scenary like rctw, or even rct2 for that matter. Some scenary items are scalable also which is awesome. Id defiantly say the scenary is the strongest part thus far.

Coaster designer is miles better then rct2 but slopes on very tall hills can still feel a little unnatural, like curve -> straight slope for a while -> Curve out at bottom. Perhaps adding another slant between the steepest and vertical would help greatly. Fury 325 for example has 81 degree drop, not quite vertical. Also some elements are limiting, 45 degree turns cant be used on slant, half loops are straight only which made making x-flight ingame impossible. Small Gripes but i enjoy recreating real parks so its mildly annoying for me.

UI and all that is basic but it functions perfectly, staff screen is a bit clunky but overall cant complain considering its EA.

The cons would be there is no tutorial or any kind of handholding at this point in devolopment, you just have a sandbox to play in basically. So if you really have no past experience with rct or would give up in confusion quickly then sure, avoid till it has tutorial.

Overall ive enjoyed every minute so far and look foward to the future updates and feel it was worth every penny thus far. Devs seem very involved with the community and the game so i have high hopes it will actually reach release given no monitary issues.

Pick up Parkitect, pick up Planet Coaster, pretend like RTC World doesn't exist and you will love both games.

If you can't tell from all my gushing, I very highly recommend Parkitect. It's a must-buy!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early Access Watcher Reviews Parkitect

Upgrade Version: Update 95

Disclosure: This game copy was bought by the reviewer.

I was a little young to really grasp the first Rollercoaster Tycoon and had a chance to briefly engage in the sequel before the third game in the series came out. The micromanagement and artistic freedom to design incredible rides and spacious parks interested me enough to try other games in the genre in the hopes of rekindling that spark. It was not easy with the mobile cash grab remake of Theme Park and the rather grotesque changes made to the newest Rollercoaster Tycoon dashing my hopes of finding another competent coaster simulator. My search has now led me to Parkitect and a potential successor to the Rollercoaster Tycoon of old. Is this new Early Access product the golden chariot bound to carry the new era of coaster simulators or just another contraption ready to send a carload of patrons plummeting to their doom?

While visuals are not a major priority with these type of games, the simple, cartoony style works well. Rides are animated beautifully and small objects such as drinks, burgers and birds are given enough noticeable detail. The music is pleasant, but it gets repetitive very quickly. Attendees frequently speak in a bizarre Sim-like mumbling that complements the screams and laughter of riders. The atmosphere really feels as if it was ripped straight out of an old coaster sim.

If it looks like a duck and sounds like a duck, does it mean it is a duck? In this case, it isn't. The only available mode right now is the Sandbox mode, allowing players to build and test out the rides with no negative repercussions or goals outside of not going bankrupt. It is enough to give people the tools to sink hours into customizing their own dream parks, but it is missing the challenge and variety of mission based scenarios other roller coaster sims provide. It might be enough for some players, but others looking for some meat with their potatoes might be disappointed in the lack of diverse game modes.

It offers 20 flat rides (motion rides, haunted houses), 13 coasters and 3 transport rides along with 21 shops and utilities. You also get the standard security, janitor, entertainer, and mechanic employees to hire. One special entry I noticed was the hauler employee, which takes supplies brought to the park and carries it to the different shops and kiosks to keep them supplied. I did like this addition, which gave the park a more realistic feel. You can also read the thoughts of attendees, adjust ticket prices, construct coasters and buildings free hand, and change the ride speeds. Time can also be enhanced using the speed up function.

The problems start to arrive once the parks grows to a mid-terrain size and large numbers of attendees begin to inhabit the area. Loading into these larger parks has caused me to lock up a couple of times and the rest of the time severe frame rate lose was experienced. It is clear the larger the size of your park the more strain it puts on the game, which results in the frame rate issues. The lack of a tutorial can also cause newer players some trouble if they are not accustom to the genre. Requirements such as queue lines, employee territory coverage and ride status can be hard to locate without prior knowledge. The deletion key, set to the right click, can also cause some heavy annoyance as accidental clicks can remove anything you are working on.

It is possible to spend a good chunk of time create some fairly decent parks using the tools already provide, but it does not offer much to encourage repeat visits. Placing and building can be satisfying, but with no real goals or motivations you end up resorting to murder by flying coaster cars to keep things interesting. This is a better alternative to Roller Coaster Tycoon World, by far, but it is a better option to continuing with the classic Roller Coaster Tycoon while this game is developed further. It is an interesting tech demo for what is to come, but the price of admission is just not justified for what is here. Hopefully in the future this park will expand to something great, but at this point now you are better off waiting to purchase this ticket.

Pros

- Looks rather good
- Coaster and building customization

Cons

- Lack of a tutorial for newcomers to the genre
- Loading freezes (could be based on next negative)
- Frame rate drops when park increases to a certain size
- Very easy to accidentally delete something

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I like a simple coaster game.  It doens't need to be so advanced that it takes up several gbs and lags. It doesn't need to be so advanced that things stop making sense, because the creators were in over their heads.

This game delivers. It's simple where it hardly matters (such as grass), and it focuses its powers on the game design, such as creating your park. The game is really easy to understand and the processes, whether it's building a road or a coaster, are really smooth.

I've been waiting for RCTworld for so long now, and I realize, after having found this game, that THIS GAME is everything RCTworld wants to be, but has failed at achieving - so far.

This game delivers. It's cheap. It's easy to use. It's well-made.

I have this feeling that it's RCT-fans who has made the game. They took the good things from RCT and made it into a game. It's awesome.

Definitely recommendable - even as early access. There's so much potential!
